nameEntry.part: Crossroads West Hollywood Children's Village residential unit

biogHist.abstract: Hollywood Children's Village was the new name given in 1965 to the Salvation Army Boys' Home (in Nedlands). Cottages were built to house the boys from this time. In 1969, after the Salvation Army Girls' Home, Cottesloe closed, girls were admitted. Children who were wards and private children were admitted until the Village closed in 1994.
biogHist.p: Hollywood Children's Village was the new name given to the Salvation Army Boys' Home, Nedlands, in 1965. At first it accommodated only boys, but girls were admitted from 1969. More than 300 children and young people were admitted between 1965 and 1991. From 1990, only teenagers were admitted. In 1991 the residential program was renamed 'Crossroads west'. In 1994, the one remaining residential cottage at the Hollywood Children's Village site closed. The site is now an aged care facility.

Brand House, later called Brand Cottage or just 'Brand', opened in 1965, with the official ceremony on 3 July. Sir David Brand was a Premier of Western Australia. Pied Piper Cottage ('Piper') opened in 1966 and its opening ceremony was on 23 October of that year. Each of these cottages housed up to 12 children, supervised by cottage parents. In 1966, there were 52 boys in total on the Nedlands site, so some boys were apparently still accommodated in dormitories.

A newspaper article, 'Families share their affection and fellowship', written around 1969 reported that all 36 children at the Village had been referred by the Child Welfare Department and that they returned to their parents in the Christmas holidays. At that stage, the children at the Village were aged 7-15 years and according to the news item, 'some had been at the cottage for five years and would probably stay longer' though the aim was to reunite children with their families. A description of the facilities was given: Meals were prepared in a main kitchen and served in dining rooms with four tables in the cottages; cottage fathers worked outside the Village; children of different ages slept in one, two or three-bed rooms in each cottage; some children had part-time jobs; some had pocket-money from parents and others were given pocket-money by Village authorities.

Withnell Cottage opened on 25 January 1970. By 1996, Withnell Cottage was the headquarters of the Salvation Army Historical Society. In 2005 it was used by the aged care facility as a library and for storage.

Signposts records the location ot Cottesloe House as the Hollywood Children's Village, Nedlands, but more recent research by Find & Connect historian, Debra Rosser has confirmed that Cottesloe House was located in Mt Lawley.

At the start of 1971, the Hollywood Children's Village was put under the management of the Superintendent of the adjacent Salvation Army Senior Citizens' Village. A swimming pool for children was officially opened on 27 March 1971 and the Children's Choir sang at the ceremony.

By 1990, around half the children referred to Hollywood were over 12 years old and the Salvation Army considered the cottage parent style of accommodation unsuitable for teenagers. There was a transition to an 'expanded youth program', focusing on teenagers. From 18 May 1990, there were no more admissions of children to the Hollywood Children's Village and by January 1991, there was only one residential unit at Hollywood, for teenagers. That unit was part of the Salvation Army's Crossroads west program and the administration of Crossroads west was run from the Hollywood site.
When the residential programs for children and young people at Hollywood ceased in 1994, the buildings were used for the Salvation Army's Eventide Home for Men.

In 1997, the buildings that had been Brand, Pied Piper and Buckingham Cottages were demolished and 'Cottesloe Cottage' was at that time the only remaining building from the Children's Village. It, too, has since been demolished.

chronItem.event: Location - The Hollywood Children's Village was located in Hollywood (or Nedlands) in Perth.

descriptiveNote.p: After the Salvation Army Girls' Home, Cottesloe closed, girls were admitted to the Hollywood Children's Village, Salvation Army.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Salvation Army Book Records and Miscellaneous Files (1898 - 1970)

descriptiveNote.p: The 'Book Records Nedlands/Hollywood (Admittance Book, 1968-1970)' in the Salvation Army Book Records and Miscellaneous Files collection may contain records relating to the Hollywood Children's Village.

descriptiveNote.p: Some young people who had been resident at Hollywood Children's Village, Salvation Army were placed at Landsdale House.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Department of Aboriginal Affairs [predecessors], Records, Department of Aboriginal Affairs (1886 - 2004)

descriptiveNote.p: Alinjarra Cottage offered emergency and short-term care at Hollywood Children's Village, Salvation Army, where the other cottages were set up for medium to long-term care.
Some boys who had been resident at Withnell House may have moved to the Hollywood Children's Village, Salvation Army.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.abstract: 'Children's village office' is a digital copy of an undated colour photograph held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It is likely that most children were brought to the office as part of their admission to the Hollywood Children's Village.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Demolition, Brand and Pied Piper Cottages

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.unittitle: Demolition, Brand and Pied Piper Cottages
archref.abstract: 'Demolition, Brand and Pied Piper Cottages' is a digital copy of an undated colour photograph held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. A handwritten caption says that the red truck in the photograph is in front of Brand and the yellow truck is outside Piper. The demolition year, 1996, has been used to date this image.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Bedroom with desk, Hollywood Children's Village

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.unittitle: Bedroom with desk, Hollywood Children's Village
archref.abstract: 'Bedroom with desk, Hollywood Children's Village' is a digital copy of an undated colour image held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Pied Piper Cottage and Brand House plaques

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.unittitle: Pied Piper Cottage and Brand House plaques
archref.abstract: 'Pied Piper Cottage and Brand House plaques' is a digital copy of a colour image held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It shows the plaques that were unveiled at the opening ceremonies for Brand House (3 July 1965) and Pied Piper Cottage (23 October 1966). It is unknown when the photograph was taken but it is possible that it was after the cottages had been demolished, with the plaques preserved at that time.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.abstract: 'Buckingham Cottage' is a digital copy of an insert held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The insert has two site plans of the Salvation Army facilities at Hollywood, with the location of Buckingham Cottage and the swimming pool highlighted; an image (taken 1994) of cottage parents; an excerpt from a newspaper article, 'Families share their affection and fellowship' about the village (probably from 1969) reporting on accommodation arrangements at the Village; an item, 'Saturday: double opening' from the War Cry in 1971 about the swimming pool at the Village; a photograph dated 1994 showing the demolition of the Brand and Pied Piper cottages; and two coloured photocopies of an older cottage at the Salvation Army Boys' Home, Nedlands (West Subiaco).

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.abstract: 'Salvation Army Hollywood site plan' is a digital copy of a photocopied map held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The site plan shows the location of Brand, Pied Piper, Buckingham and Cottesloe Cottages on the Hollywood Children's Village site, bordered by Smyth Road and Karella Street. The location of Brand Cottage is highlighted. The swimming pool is shown in the aged care grounds. It is unknown when this site plan was prepared but the swimming pool did not open until 1971, so it was after that and probably before the Village closed in 1994.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.abstract: 'Hollywood Children's Village 1980s' is a digital copy of a colour image held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. A handwritten caption gives the location and year. The image shows a basketball court, climbing frame and other play equipment.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hollywood Children's Village file
archref.abstract: 'The Salvation Army Hollywood Village' is a digital copy of an image held in the Hollywood Children's Village file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It is held with other images relating to a 'Back to Hollywood Day' in 1994 so probably dates from then. The image shows a model locating all the facilities on the Nedlands (Hollywood) site, including the Children's Village and the aged care facility.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Comfort at Institution for Children' is a photocopy of an article from what is possibly The West Australian newspaper held in the Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The purpose of the article is to encourage people to donate funds to help build the Hollywood Children's Village. There are photographs and descriptions of the interior of the first cottage (Brand Cottage), and a floor plan.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Girls' bedroom' is a digital copy of an undated photograph held in the Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The toys suggest the room was set up for primary school-aged girls so it is likely to have been a new room in a girls' cottage, possibly at the Hollywood Children's Village. The 'candlewick' bedspread and blondewood wardrobe were popular in 1960s Perth. There appears to be another bed visible in the reflection of the wardrobe mirror.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Hollywood Children's Village, aerial photograph' is a digital copy of an undated photograph held in the Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. From other information in the file, it is likely that the buildings shown are (clockwise from left) Pied Piper, Brand, and Buckingham Cottages, the gymnasium and the administration block. The photograph can be dated from 1969, when Buckingham Cottage opened.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file
archref.abstract:
'Hollywood Children's Village, aerial view' is a a digital copy of an undated photocopy held in the Nedlands Boys Home closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. A typed list in the file identifies the numbered buildings that are visible on the photocopy, showing the different eras of the property. The list has a note that alerts readers to possible omissions and mis-identification of buildings.
On the right of the photocopy is the site of the original Karrakatta Prison Gate Farm which became the Salvation Army Boys' Home (1 and 2).
On the left, are the newer cottages of the Hollywood Children's Village: Pied Piper Cottage (13); Brand Cottage (14); Buckingham Cottage (15); Cottesloe, also known as 'Withnell' Cottage (16); Cook's Cottage (17); Gymnasium, with a kitchen at the rear to service the cottages (18); Administration Block, including welfare officers' interview rooms, homework room and library (19); and Vegetable Gardens and Sports Oval (22). The other buildings form the Salvation Army Senior Citizens' Village.
The aerial view must have been taken after 1970, which is when Cottesloe (Withnell) Cottage opened.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Withnell House child home closed file
archref.abstract: 'Withnell House' is a digital copy of a history paper, prepared by The Salvation Army Historical Society, that is held in the Withnell House child home closed [File, Salvation Army] file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA.
